headline: Work-life balance valued,
pros:
HR is adamant that they will only hire those with a good attitude, so all of my co-workers are reasonable adults who are very self-aware. No office drama! Unbelievable!

Compensation very fair, great benefits.  Managers are encouraged to develop their team members' careers.  Administrative employees are treated as equals with lots of potential for growth.
cons: There are no cons that I can think of that aren't average for any workplace.

headline: Summer Internship
pros:
I really liked working at Autodesk. They have a great team, everyone is really friendly and the bureaucracy is better than in most big companies. My Manager was very encouraging.

They give their interns good relocation benefits and compensation is competitive. Autodesk also hires a lot of its interns.

There are a lot of intern events, but if you're interning in the SF Bay Area, I would recommend trying to get an internship in the San Francisco office and not in San Rafael. You'll definitely feel more a part of the Autodesk culture and can participate in all the activities.
cons: I didn't notice any major issues. The overall experience was very positive. I recommend doing an internship here, but for long-term employment, I think the current situation is a little volatile, because they are going through some business transitions. As a result, there's a lot of instability.

headline: Great place to work

headline: Having Ownership as an Intern

headline: Great Company.  Trying To Be More Like Silicon Valley

cons: Difficult to increase compensation, especially if you start at a low level.  Not all divisions work well together.  Technical teams are Agile, but the business is still stuck in old management styles.

headline: Excellent experience

headline: Cool company, but lots of hierarchy
pros: Really fun environment, SF office is beautiful. Culture is very nice, not long hours.  Really cool products that change the world.
cons: Too many directors who do not do enough actual work. Too much overlap between the different business groups. My team's project got killed when our leader decided that there was a competing technology within another business that was too similar, but that we had never heard of.

headline: Cool company that's stuck 20 years in the past

-The Sustainability and Foundation team is doing amazing work with non-profits
-Great benefits and salary
cons:
-Not very diverse (mostly white males)
-Toxic company culture (everyone is very competitive and willing to throw others under the bus to get ahead)
-Many processes and systems are extremely outdated because Autodesk hasn't had to innovate as it's been the market leader and giant in its areas for so long.
-No opportunities for career growth for young employees (or for more senior employees for that matter)

headline: Good place to work, trying to catch up to modern Internet company

cons: It's work hard, play hard if you are in a key product, engineering or marketing job. People work a lot from M-F but get freedom and plentiful PTO. The sales organization is not the best.

headline: Good place to work, trying to catch up to modern Internet company

headline: As corporations go, this one is a keeper
pros:
Too many to list, but here goes anyway.
Tone at the top. Marching orders from CEO are "get out there and build a better world." Pretty hard to argue with that.
The company funds original research into all sorts of things. This attracts people who are not just corporate drones and zombies, and is one of the best recruiting tools I've ever witnessed.
The company is rapidly transitioning from a fast follower into a thought leader.
Cool office space.
Even cooler range of software.
Outstanding, well intentioned, responsible people for the most part.
cons: Some Wall Street hedge funds have noticed that Autodesk has a vision that extends past the end of the current fiscal quarter. It remains to be seen if they can learn to tolerate an altruistic business model that wants to do good things to benefit ALL stakeholders over an extended period of time.

headline: On par a positive experience

headline: Autodesk Leader

headline: Fun place to work
pros: Work life balance: was one of the best environments I have worked in.  I felt that co-workers were willing to collaborate and were very welcoming to new ideas.  Really fun, interesting, very innovative product solutions. Generally management was very supportive management and listened to employees’ ideas and concerns.  Overall one of the better companies I have worked for.  Wish I didn't leave.
cons: A lot of internal job changes can be disruptive for projects.  In some departments managers have been in the same position of many years which limits upward mobility.  Probably explains why more lateral job movements internally.

headline: Great for Quality of Life, not for growth
pros: Interesting technology, great teams, great work/life balance.

headline: Great company. Even greater if you are in or close to HQ
pros: Great culture, great work environment and products that make an impact on the world. The leadership tries hard to steer the company to be cutting edge and innovative:
cons:
Many times it feels leaders within the organization are not held responsible for their decisions. For example a Director or a VP makes a decision or embarks on an initiative and even before the real effects of that decision is realized, that Director or VP is already celebrated and promoted or is asked to move onto something else.

Currently the company seems to be in a bit of an identity crisis trying to be a cloud company without a clear idea of what makes a cloud company. 

Many times all the decisions to be too centered around San Francisco!

headline: a good place to work
pros: Great benefits, Great Salery, work/life balance is good especially compared to some others in the Bay area software industry. Also good internal opportunity for advancement
cons: Not exciting, frequent management changes

headline: The good is great, the bad is lame...
pros: Anything that Autodesk can do to be nice to employees, as long as it requires only spending money and no complex thought, they do.  The reward package is second to none and generally speaking people are very pleasant.  Autodesk also has a lot of market influence so you can often hope to work on something that gets used a lot by customers doing exciting work.
cons: Planning and organisation are things which never touch Autodesk at any point.  Internally they are chaotic with departments and teams working at complete cross-purposes all over the place.  They politics is also unhealthy -- not in the sense of evil or repressive, but more in the sense of all the decision making happens miles from the work-face...  Senior managers are impossibly remote and irrelevant.  Middle managers have no idea what the actual detailed issues facing the company are, so instead generate a stream of spin and "initiatives" which in theory drive the company but actually just gets in the way.  Projects are launched with great fanfare, planned only in the broadest terms, then teams spend some years trying to live with the Realpolitik in a way which still permits them to do something useful.  After that the project never ends, instead it is just quietly forgotten and there is never any objective attempt to determine whether it succeeded.  Frequently you will find yourself doing what you know is the wrong thing, but which has the correct politically acceptable labels associated with it.

headline: Finance Manager
pros: Great culture, smart people, great benefits, competitive salaries, interesting work. The company is willing to promote and provide more opportunity if the employees can show they ready and willing.
cons: In the last 2 years the company culture has changed. Longevity at the company is not valued and the culture has changed for the worse.

headline: Exciting for Bay Area, less so for many other offices
pros: Autodesk is doing/making great stuff and moving in interesting directions. Its brand is more recognized across a wider spectrum of the public.
cons: Yet... while the company says it needs people who embrace change and innovation to successfully weather a big business transformation, when it comes down to it, they mean they need 99%+ of those people in the Bay Area. There is a chronic lack of skill or priority to involve talent outside of the SF Bay Area except a few major hubs. Is it harder to collaborate and cooperate across geos? Yes, but if you don't, this results in solutions that are unconsciously US-centric. This is not truly a global company in thought and deed and culture, but merely in sales of products.

I enjoyed working there. The treated their employees well and even when I was laid off they did right by me. They respected the need for work/life balance .

People

headline: A very employee focused place to work
pros: Great products and overall good staff. Very focused on work life balance and achievement. If you perform then you are left to manage your business. Geat internal structure and well organised. Recomend to anyone with an appetite to learn and prove what you can do.
cons: Some "legacy" managers still in place, keeping their friends in positions of power when they could / should have been moved on long ago. Some internal departments are at odds / do not align together when they should.

headline: Great working environment for interns
pros: Staff are friendly. There are multiple recreational corners whereby employees can sit and drink coffee, play table tennis, Xbox 360, and table football. The seniors are also very willing to teach and guide interns when they face problems. Competitive salary package as well.
cons: There are no particular cons per se. However, work can be relatively dull or monotonous depending on your job scope.

headline: Technical Support Manager
pros: Great company to work for. Great benefits, competitive pay, good health benefits, 401K, holidays, can work from home 1 day per week.
cons: Lack of direction from Sr Management

headline: Sales
pros: Sabbatical program, week of rest during holidays
cons: NO work life balance, sales management is in disarray, NO upward movement without being part of the "mentor mafia", Totally unqualified first line managers.

headline: Challenging and Engaging
pros: I love working at Autodesk! The company is full of smart, engaged people that are focused on a powerful mission. Excellent perks, benefits, and employees are given a lot of autonomy.
cons: Global team structures can slow down execution.

headline: Change for the worse.
pros: Great benefits, normal salary, lenient schedules.
cons:
Technical Support in particular is in shambles. They are turning it into a revolving door of under-qualified, under-paid, call center personnel.

I have been here 1 year and change and have seen 2 MASSIVE layoffs, and other cherry picking of laying off others.

NO ONE IS HAPPY with the current state of the support organization.

From what I hear, other departments are not in as bad of shape, but global customer support is being run by people who have very unclear, and illogical decision making abilities.

There is NO room for advancement... that would mean more work for middle management that holds it thumb on you (for 8+ years in some cases)... they would have to backfill your position.

headline: Good and Bad company so watch out!! Transformative Business Decisions means shareholders count more than employees.
pros: Good compensation and perks compared to industry - great to ride the gravy train in short term. Some nice people work there.
cons: No future unless YOU LICK the right BUTTS constantly or else you'll slide into the terminate list - especially when $$ are needed to impress stock holders

headline: Software Architect

cons: Senior management staff i.e. from Senior Directors and up, do not make independent decisions. Very much a herd instinct. Cross the wrong influential person, and your career is down the drain.

headline: Senior Software Architect

headline: Almost good...if you work in the right divisions...for the right people..
pros:
Competitive Pay

Some divisions are very successful cad/ plant manufacturing software/ mechanical construction software - all do really well 

Great office locations globally

Bass was great live and one on one

Company disposition regarding sustainability is admirable and sensible 

Clever competitive licensing models still ahead of their time

Fantastic medical plan 

Strong finance teams

Financial strength - can exert tremendous energy at any opportunity or issue when so desired

Early internal education and training was great - interviewing within the law/hiring within the law super valuable
cons:
Orwellian forced personality testing (Meyers Briggs) you WILL comply

Rotating door of managers ( 15-20 in 15 years) one can't really make a plan and work it before another manager appears

Short term senior sales management taking years of revenue off the table in one deal then moving to a diff division- tough luck next year - not my problem 

Senior managers are ultra political and you aren't part of the group

Stack ranking with a heap of good old boy games thrown in ( when I was there) 

No real resolve for international ownership of accounts - like working at 4 separate companies 

Mandatory education in a vertical you don't work for isn't helpful its indoctrination.
Education unrecognized by HR records isn't helpful if you ever move on

Temporary amnesia at year end, and quarterly forgetfulness happen regularly 
 
Piracy dept varies dramatically from keystone cops to pretty good

Work life balance - out of balance

headline: Was a good company
pros:
Very good work-life balance. People usually just work a few hours every day. 
The pay is not low but not high either. 
The company is not customer facing. And its products have sticky fact -- once the designers start using it, switching to another one is risky and costly. So it is sort of stable.
It is still dominating building industry and 2D CAD area. I tried a few other 2D softwares. They are far worse than AutoCAD.
cons:
The reason why I give it one star is because of three reasons (without them the company deserves 3 stars): 
1. when I leave the company recently, there is no exist interview. My manager asked HR but no response. The company doesn't care why you want to leave. 
2. I worked long enough time that I earn a sabbatical, which is 6 weeks paid vacation. I did not get payment for this when I left the company. So I sent email to HR asking for this. I did not get any response either. 
3. Early this year I had a friend who wanted to partner with Autodesk. So I sent an email to a senior sales manager asking how to do so. I did not get response.

Apparently people working there just want to get paid. They are not passionate. This is the reason why I wanted to leave too. Only a few percentages of people really working hard -- I know a few of them. The rest are just lying in their chairs, sometimes making negative contributions.  The company doesn’t pay excellent people enough – a few thousand dollar difference won’t encourage people to work harder and overtime. If you are smart and want to get paid for your contribution, don’t go there.

Not much growth. It is not one of the top three companies in 3D manufacturing industry. Since going from 2D to 3D is inevitable, it is losing its foundation. When their old customers (designers) retire, the company will suffer.

Pay is okay -- can't compete with the hot companies in bay area. Even startups can beat it.  If you just want a job, this is a good company to work with.

headline: Great place marred by a huge lack of morals at the top
pros: Smart, dedicated people.  Direct managers care, or at most seem to.  Above average benefits for the industry.  Smart people.  Great opportunity to advance to middle management.  Above average work life balance.  It would be the ideal place to work if not...
cons:
The people at the helm will gut engineering departments and replace them with engineers in Bangalore and/or Shanghai, or fresh out of school, to meet the bottom line and appease Wall Street.  They've done it before, they'll do it again. Beware.

If this company didn't own the DWG format they would have died decades ago.  AutoCAD profit has allowed them to buy their way into other industries, and gobble up competition, and then over time release those engineers and replace them with cheaper talent either overseas or right from school.  They have done this time and time again.  It's a modern day form of corporate raiding.

It is a terrible way to run a business, and it is a reason why they can't grow ANY software in house and have it succeed, outside of Autocad and it's verticals.  Virtually all successful products beyond these have been ACQUIRED, and of those products, at least 50% of the engineers are gone within 5 years.  It's sad, really.

headline: Great software company
pros:
Toronto office. Great mix of people, different ages and backgrounds. Lots of experienced HCI people as well as some of the industry top software engineers. 
Great work life balance, culture and opportunities to learn. 
Lots of innovation happening. Work is meaningful, products are meant to help solve real life problems.
Company is environmentally and socially conscious.
cons:
New teams and protocols come by way of acquisition so collaboration can be challenging. 
Silos exist between different teams as well as parts of the team, like ba's, ux, pm's. Remote collaboration across geos is also challenging.
Some products get deprioritized or end up in parked mode due to business requirements.
Process is predominantly engineering driven which downplays design strategy role.

headline: Good company minus the constant restructuring
pros:
The company is actually a good place to work if not for the constant state of restructuring. 
Good benefits and package
Open and friendly environment
Flexible hours
cons:
Constant restructuring
Buys more tech than they actually build
Constant changing of high - mid level objectives
Lack of long term vision from senior management

headline: Could be better
pros:
- Good benefits and perks, if that is what you are looking for (not my case).
- Good work life balance, flexible working hours, friendly and relaxed office environment.
- Transformation ongoing with encouraging things to come.
cons:
- Some old fashioned management techniques, favouritism, top down decisions. But people working in the Singapore office seem to be accustomed to that (lots of EP holders).
- Definitely not an Agile company yet, too many management layers and limited team autonomy. This is a work in progress but mentalities will take time to change.
- Inefficient process and "hero" mentality, instead of streamlined robust team-based development and deliveries.
- Too many restructurations, and one 10% lay-off this year : the strategy seems to be based on the stock markets' and investors' reactions, and the employees just pay the price.

headline: Squizz employees and Customers for shareholders short term profit only
pros: Autodesk tries to build a long term vision over its products.
cons: The company has no any consideration for its employees (the ones who produce something from their brain) and its clients. the only targer it to inclrease the subscribers numbers in order to provide quarter acceptable numbers for its shareholders.

headline: Senior Software Engineer

friendly environment
Good pay

only c++

no flexi timing

except developers , all people get chances to fly to US, UK etc

headline: Great company

Culture and Values

Benefits

cons: Too many politics. Tech is not the most important thing and even it's the most unimportant. You have to say more and do less, and you are even required to be such gay by your manager. Making your boss happy is the most important point, even he is totally wrong.

headline: Good working environment
pros: Good working environment, flexible working hour

headline: Great perks, cool place, lots of politics
pros: Great perks and benefits. Healthcare, 401k, stock are all better than average. Always something really cool going on at the office. Cutting edge design around you all the time. Very inspiring. Work-life balance is fantastic.
cons: Politics are rampant and severely slow down progress. Frequent re-orgs, and people in leadership roles that are not always the strongest.

headline: Great Place
pros: Great benefits and a fun culture
cons: Politics, but typical in corporate world

headline: Awful middle management
pros: The CEO has a vision and the company makes interesting products
cons: Appalling middle management, senior managers who at best do nothing but occasionally are just around to messing up hard working IC contributions.  Directors, some good some bad, act with complete impunity, firing high performers because they are threatening, promoting incompetent managers only because they will mindlessly ask ICs to do anything.

headline: Principal Engineer

pros: Great benefits, employee perks and work life balance.

headline: Good Luck
pros: Free Lunch, Nice offices, not much else to say here.
cons: Beauracratic and political.  Those that have managed to survive for a few years are preoccupied with continuing their own survival through the annual layoffs.  New employees are thrown into the mix and their survival is directly related to the political skills of their manager.  Middle management is incompetent. The company struggles to make decisions and then operationalize them before changing direction. In job postings this is described as a "dynamic work environment" That's an attempt to put a positive spin on what is in reality weak uninspired leadership. I was also surprised to find that they under pay.

headline: Finance

Acquires more software than it develops.
Change of company direction every other year.
Chasing buzzwords, lack commitment to long-term technology advancement.

headline: Engineer
pros: diversity, fast, learning, cloud, potential

headline: Director
pros: Good compensation and benefits.  Resources available for execution.  In a strong position which can be even stronger.  Activist investors offer hope of cleaning out stagnant senior management.

headline: AutoCAD org
pros:

Majority of them 20+ years at the company 
Rich line & legacy of features 
Reasonably innovative 
Great set of co-workers in general
cons:
AutoCAD management is a sore spot. 
Top heavy, plagued by politics, lack of vision, lack of transparency 
Episodic & random layoff decisions every few years....poor choice of who is let go. 
Just announced 10% massive layoff in 2016, took everyone by surprise
As a consequence, affects employee morale
Bias towards tenured employees 

In other words, management really sucks

headline: Toronto office has great culture
pros: One of the best companies to be employed by. A large corporation with lot's of different teams in different locations all of which have their own ways of working. Toronto office has a great culture, people of all different ages, great social events, lot's of talented people working together. The company has great health benefits, stock purchase plan, RRSP matching and a very nice office including showers and bike room!
cons: Just as in any large company there's a lot of noise at the managerial level and it can be hard to navigate the agenda du jour, but individual contributors rarely have to deal with any of the politics. Sometimes business decisions being made don't seem to make sense from your stand point and the trickling down of communications from VP to producer level isn't always the greatest but great work and innovation still gets done all around.

headline: Deal Operations Manager
pros: People, people, people!  Work- life balance.  Dogs in some offices.
cons: Global process may not always be a good fit!

headline: Great company to work for
pros: Great culture, super nice management, very good life-work balance, good pay
cons: No much room for career development

headline: Good place to work
pros:
Great & smart people to work with
Great culture
Less politics involved
cons: Very fast pace, a lot of things changed quickly..

headline: Terrible mess
pros: None I could think of
cons: Too many to list. Just stay away!

headline: Great company, but Management needs training
pros: Excellent product, reputation, location, etc.  Autodesk has very good benefits and the people are generally great.  Jobs are varied and interesting, but don't expect to work only 40 hours/week -- it is a high-pressure place and many employees work between 50-60 hours/week, often late into the night and on weekends. As a global company, you can expect to have a call with Europe in the morning and then a call at night with Asia. Be clear on your boundaries.
cons: Success at Autodesk depends on how good your manager is.  If you get a young, inexperienced manager, deliverables are unclear and inconclusive causing frustration and confusion. With a more experienced, knowledgable manager, communication is better and expectations can be met.  It's important to get clear direction on ambiguous projects so as to avoid mixed messages. Find out as much as you can about your manager's experience and how long people have been in your group before signing on.

headline: Sr. Finance Business Partner
pros: Great people.  Global company with cool offices around the world.
cons: Constant reorgs and layoffs.  Senior management is very short term focused.

headline: Director
pros: Visionary Company with results oriented culture, strong benefits package with unlimited PTO at Director level and 6 week paid time off after 4 years.  Great products and leader in many of the industries that is markets to.
cons: Duplication in too many areas slows decision making and ability to drive change faster.

headline: Pretty poor
pros:
This applies to the ex-Delcam office in Birmingham as of April 2016

-Friendly people, on the most part 
-Interesting work, some of the time
-Excellent working hours. I work an 8 hour day and from home on a Friday

Generally all three of these are getting worse as the Autodesk takeover gathers speed.
cons:
This applies to the ex-Delcam office in Birmingham as of April 2016

-Terrible communication.
-Poor senior management though in fairness they aren't helped by the cliquey, siloed and poorly-structured workings of our Autodesk parent company.
-Salary and benefits are low for the Birmingham area which is noticeable considering the bulk of engineers here have Masters and PhDs from Russell Group universities.

A lot of Delcam is explained by it's history. One of the many CADCAM companies to start around the 60s and 70s (Autodesk, now our parent company, started about that time) it was originally a research group based out of Cambridge. Now it's a much larger company based out of Birmingham. The original founders have left but the first generation haven't. The result is a very close knit family feel at the top, but not much room for movement otherwise. Throw in Autodesk, an aggressive, fast-moving company with a poor track record for integrating acquisitions and you can imagine where Delcam is now.

Do not, I repeat do not, come to work for this company.

headline: Good people, poor management creates low morale and uncertainty.
pros: The majority of people are nice and genuine that do help each other out. Projects tend to be challenging and working with the larger Autodesk group means opportunities to know some talented individuals.
cons: Constant restructuring and the short tenure of some positions means you don't have enough time to make any significant impact. Career advancement is limited outside of the core US operations and internal appraisals are peace meal or non existent. The location leaves much to be desired and although facilities are in the process of being upgraded people do not see much of an improvement to the working environment.

headline: Big and publicly traded but too terribly stiff inside
pros: Systems and equipment are top-notch, internal helpdesk always responsive, travel is a breeze, opportunities to work with real pros who are doing exciting things, facilities are very pleasant, company culture adapts to customs of the local geo, felt like my contributions were valuable and appreciated.
cons: Sometimes it felt like the company was a little too big for its britches. No consistency across dev teams (I do understand that different softwares require different bug management systems and methods of development but it was a little out of control). Hard to get information on products that were more mature in their lifecycle.

headline: Great place to work
pros: The people - involved, educated, wonderful to work with.  Also with so many products, there is the ability to work on a wide range of applications on a variety of development platforms. Nice perks like monthly work hours social gatherings, provided snacks, monthly lunch.
cons: working cube environment can be noisy - but is workable most of the time

headline: Great place to work
pros: The people - involved, educated, wonderful to work with.  Also with so many products, there is the ability to work on a wide range of applications on a variety of development platforms. Nice perks like monthly work hours social gatherings, provided snacks, monthly lunch.

headline: Too Much Bureaucracy

cons:
Too much politics
Too many layers of management
Difficult to affect change
Frequent layoffs
Stuffy culture in some parts of the company
No opportunities for growth/learning in certain positions
Lack of flexibility (hours & location)
Work is plentiful, but not challenging
Management makes frequent changes for no reason
Not open to disagreements
Open office arrangement

headline: Great company, but no internal growth
pros: It's a great company because they hire smart people and encourage continuous reflection of business models and process to support future revenue growth. A very forward-thinking company in this respect.
cons: I did not find a clear path to manage my personal career growth. HR said to work with direct manager; yet direct managers did not have career development budget or skills. This aspect was not forward-thinking, and they are losing some bright minds and motivated people.

headline: Good company
pros:
1. Very good work culture & good people
2. Open environment
3. Work life balance is manageable
4. Highly recommend who is really interested in solving difficult challenges, but that too depend on which project you are working on.
cons: Be ready for drastic changes every couple of months (team, project, technology)

headline: so so
pros:
Flexible working hour is great. 
Good work life balance.
cons: Still developing desktop products using very old technology. Lack of growth opportunity

headline: Partner Services representative
pros: easy work,  flexibility for work from home,  a lot co.  / team activities
cons: Unfair treatment towards employees. Managers usually favour their own favorites.

headline: Sr. Sales Manager
pros: Great Benefits, cool company culture, great products, California-style work-life balance, excellent top management, cool offices, above average salaries ( in the US), great partners network, being the absolute leader in its market adds to employee resume. SaaS strategy is sound on paper.
cons: Not a global company yet but an American company with overseas operations, no competitve salaries outside US, poor professional services offerings, mediocre Mid Level management,  difficult to have a ascending career ( except if you a former Mentor Graphics boy), CEO focus on Consumer needs vs Corporate needs sends a mixed signal to employees. and market.  SaaS transition still a risk

headline: Change is not for wimps
pros: Great environment, interesting work, good team support and interaction. Excellent benefits and opportunities to contribute to making a difference.
cons: Constant change and not always implemented most effectively. Much more work to do than can possibly be done in a 40 hour work week.

headline: Program Manager
pros: Great Benefits, awesome people to work with - everyone is working towards the company's success. Everyone is very helpful.
cons: As a large organization, it is very silo'd, which sometimes makes it difficult to navigate who to talk to within the organization.

headline: Solid, stable employement
pros: It is family friendly as many employees have young families so there is flexibiliity.  As long as you do your role well, it doesn't matter if you need some timing flexibilty.  It is a positive, open culture.
cons:
It is very difficult to move up, as there is minimal turnover at higher levels of organization.  The most valuable way to move up is to have strong executive relationships.  Who you know is more important than what you do.

Executive management gets too involved in lower level decisions.

headline: "Great place to work"
pros: good environment
cons: Bit fast, rapid, agile development

headline: The corporate politics are unbelievable
pros: Great benefits and very competitive compensation.
cons: There are few opportunities for advancement.  The management is divided up into fiefdoms and the politics are incredible.  You have to be ninja-level in corporate politics to survive there.  Also, there are far too many layers of bureaucracy to get anything accomplished.  Innovation is truly stifled.

headline: Senior Quality Analyst
pros: Great culture, always changing, exciting work
cons: Employee layoffs every few years - Company just had 10% force reduction

headline: Technical Account Manager
pros: Great people to work with while also driving intervention through technology. The Future of Making Things.
cons: Hard to make a name for yourself at such a large company.

headline: Director Sales
pros: Great company.  Culture is about as good as you will find in the Bay Area.  Very smart and successful people work at ADSK.
cons: HR is a little heavy in management.

headline: Sr. Quality Analyst
pros: Fun products to work with.
cons: The company's technologies are not keeping up with the industry.

headline: Great company, but needs improvements
pros: Innovating company, lots of products for various industries. Has great benefits (bonuses, stock options, week of rest between Christmas and New Year, and sabbatical every 4 years). Provides training and opportunities to move to different positions within the company, and you can work from home.
cons: Too many layers of management, too many meetings that cut back the time you can really do some work. Expect late night or early morning meetings with teams from different time zones. There are also too many and confusing internal work processes, and constant changes and updates to software and tools to be used, which is very disruptive especially when getting close to releasing the final product. There is a disconnect between decision makers and the people that do the work. They don't  understand the implications of their decisions. For example, changing the product name 1-2 months before the release  means that  various teams have to spend many overtime hours to finish the projects on time - and the deadlines are very strict).

headline: Learning opportunity
pros:
1. Well managed work flow.
2. Good managers.
3. Learning opportunities.
4. Good pay scale.
5. Small company size, so whatever you do, brings value to the company.
6. Healthy environment.
cons:
1. Most of the staff is highly experienced, means freshers cant enjoy much.
2. Building structure is bit older. First look barely attractive.

headline: Great company, great engineers, decent management
pros: Benefits, location, flexible work hours, remote working, cool products, innovative thinking, great people, chill vibe, lots of social interaction, good strategic position.
cons: Open office (is noisy), sometimes seems like we are chasing the shiny hype ball, salaries are on the low side, seems like promotion within is difficult, lots of legacy code (I mean, no worse than other companies this old, but still a problem), product teams seem rather siloed and mostly look out for themselves instead of working on common goals together.

headline: Autodesk is Ok
pros: Decent Incentive Package, Good Facilities
cons: Big and operates that way. Little upward mobility.

headline: Great Place to Work
pros:
Coworkers are very professional, which encourages me to learn a lot from them. 
The product AutoCAD involves a lot of different techniques. It provides me excellent chances to practice programming/debugging skills, patterns, refactoring skills and etc.
cons: Our team didn't get a lot of graphics/CAD related features those years.

headline: great company
pros:
continuous projects.
good snacks and coffee on each floor
sf office is quite easy for commute
cons: commuting to San Rafael is strenuous if you live in the south of the SF.

headline: Cool company...seems fragmented
pros: Great products and progressive company.
cons: Upward mobility is can take years.

headline: Nice company
pros: Nice environment, great vision. Treats people with a lot f respect, great strategy.
cons: Start focusing too much on share value. Great differences between local/global operations

headline: Innovation Hub
pros: Awesome Brand name. Products ranging from old MS-DOS days to Cloud platforms. Smart and committed people. Great culture and diversity. Great work life balance. Sabbatical every 4 years. Annual week of rest from Christmas to New year!
cons: Too many parallel initiatives and projects. Some teams work in very aggressive modes whereas some teams are more relaxed. Not too many research to production projects.

headline: TAM
pros: greate,fresh, arr challanging cloud, Fusion
cons: some times it aet your life

headline: Good company if work life balance is what you are looking for
pros: Autodesk has been a very comfortable place to work for. Good benefit, good work life balance. Friendly co-workers. Solving interesting and challenging problems. Good products. Still get some good engineers around.
cons: Very political place. Little growth. Incapable middle management. Unable to attract and retain top talents. Weak execution. Compensation on the low end of market.

headline: Great engineers, not so great management
pros:
The products are very interesting, and the engineers are great, supportive people. Autodesk is trying to solve real world problems and make a difference. All the intentions are good.

Work life balance depends on the team you work for, but is good in most cases. Working with teams in different time zones can be challenging, but you can use flex working hours to get things done during the day if you are expected to work at odd hours.
cons: Sometimes projects are started that make no sense to the engineers. Any discussion on why it may not work out is ignored/suppressed/discouraged. Later, you find out that the project has failed because the people working on it are now doing something else. Projects fail very quietly and are swept under the carpet. No one at the executive level is held accountable for failed projects and no analysis is done to find out what happened. And this happens over and over again, causing loss of morale.

headline: Senior Product Manager
pros: Decent work/life balance - a lot of people can work from home. Nice offices.
cons: Lack of vision and direction from senior management. Vision from executive management can be too broad, and how it applies to the different business units is not clearly defined. This leads to a lot of ambiguity and confusion.

headline: Senior Product Manager
pros: Decent work/life balance - a lot of people can work from home. Nice offices.
cons: Lack of vision and direction from senior management. Vision from executive management can be too broad, and how it applies to the different business units is not clearly defined. This leads to a lot of ambiguity and confusion.

headline: Great Company
pros:
A Multinational Corporation with a lot of opportunity to grow. 
Great leaders.
cons: I have no downsides for Autodesk.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Progressive and employee-friendly.  Its hard to make a big ship change direction, but Autodesk's senior management does a good job at keeping Autodesk relevant.
cons: None that I can think of.

headline: Great place, great people
pros: great company to work for. Sideways and upward mobility, work is valued, great and well communicated corporate vision. A lot of cutting edge projects to work on. Good work life balance and very competitive compensation.
cons: Much of the culture change being pushed with the business transformation is not being accepted at the middle management tier. Saying it and expecting it to just happen is not going to work. Make people accountable

headline: Great company, solid values
pros: Great working environment, cool technology, excellent top management, competitive salary strategy ( at least in the Mature countries)
cons: Middle management not world class, products strategy somewhat confusing, not great at customer satisfaction

headline: Inside Sales
pros: Both internal and external partners are excellent to work with -
cons: I can't think of any at this time - great place to work.

headline: Good environment, good products
pros: Good work life balance, collaborative work culture, competitive pay, lots of training and opportunity to build on your skills.
cons: The drawbacks to working here are limited career growth, communication gaps if you are on a global team, and what appears to be routine reductions in force to, I assume, boost stock price.

headline: Bias against older workers
pros: Interesting products on leading edge of reality capture, 3D printing, AR/VR, digital twins and prototyping. Strong R&D.
cons: Recent round of layoffs hit employees 55+ at a rate of 3X compared to overall employee base. Constant promotion from execs on value of interns over existing employee "domain expertise."

headline: Project Manager
pros:
Great team
Opportunity for growth
work/life balance
loved working there
cons: If you get stuck with a bad manager, you feel trapped. Not everyone is a good people manager, but you need to become one in order to move up. If you end up with someone who is on that path and manages you poorly, you may not enjoy your job. For the most part, I had great managers.

headline: Fulfilling work!
pros: Great atmosphere, brilliant colleagues, room for growth, involved management, open communication... Just a fun place to work and grow a career.
cons: Occasional long hours. Some siloing between departments. Nothing out of the ordinary for a company of this size.

headline: Small changes every few months, one retrench every 1-2 years
pros: Good place for managers.. Some works from home frequently, some just look at the monitor all day long, some just walk around and making noise in the floor. They are nothing more than a placeholder, contribute nothing to the company and the team, but earn the most and most relax.
cons: Engineers are treated as low cost, easily replaceable workers. You think you just get promoted to principal engineer previous year and you are good? Too bad, you get retrenched due to the reason that your job can be replaced by younger and cheaper engineer.

headline: Great company, but...
pros:
Strong compensation plans and benefits, and if you can stick around employment at Autodesk provides a good opportunity to put some money in the bank. There are great people who work there and the culture, while not what it was, remains very strong.The products are innovative and the company is attempting to live closer to the bleeding edge.
Life/work balance is greatly aided by the annual week of rest (Xmas to New Years) along with a 6-week paid sabbatical every 4 years.
cons: The instability is difficult to cope with over time. Although the current changes are attempting to make the revenue stream more predictable, Autodesk remains a bit of a canary in a coalmine when it comes to economic upturns and downturns. You can expect massive layoffs every 2-3 years, followed by periods of growth.

headline: Good and bad
pros: Autodesk has a great portfolio of products, well structured organisation and many opportunities for career progression.
cons: Autodesk are slow on integrating newly acquired businesses and making decisions on business strategy.

headline: Great opportunities
pros: Excellent opportunities for progression. Very structured and focused projects. Good at sharing company strategy.
cons: UK salaries poor compared to the USA. Slow to integrate acquired companies.

headline: Senior Software Engineer
pros: It is a pretty good company.
cons: I don't feel anything bad about the company.

headline: Great leadership
pros: Good work/life balance, high standards for professionalism, smart coworkers, respected leadership
cons: Not much opportunity to move around. Silo'd teams. Some managers hire/promote friends regardless of skills, experience, and team dynamics.

headline: Intership
pros: Well known good work life balance
cons: Don't have too much job opening

headline: Innovative company
pros: Lots of autonomy, leadership not afraid to make tough decisions, good communication from leadership, bright outlook for company.
cons: Leadership creates a lot of churn. Long planning cycles take away from execution.

headline: Good place to work in
pros:
1. Open, transparent environment 
2. Good benefit. Insurance covers both couple and children
3. Ative atmosphere and moves fast
cons:
- sometimes bureaucratic
- there may be unpredicated reorganization

headline: A lot of changes
pros: Great company with great people, large customer base and very diverse industry focus. Products are top rated and well established. Lots of opportunity for professional development and advancement.
cons: Operational issues. Some midlevel management do not always conduct themselves with the highest level of integrity which is often a reflection of executive management. Being a publicly traded company, stock price and shareholder return is by far the most important goal, often at the expense of productive dedicated employees. Customers and channel partners typically suffer through all of these issues creating a poor customer experience and poor customer saticfaction ratings.

headline: A lot of changes
pros: Great company with great people, large customer base and very diverse industry focus. Products are top rated and well established. Lots of opportunity for professional development and advancement.
cons: Operational issues. Some midlevel management do not always conduct themselves with the highest level of integrity which is often a reflection of executive management. Being a publicly traded company, stock price and shareholder return is by far the most important goal, often at the expense of productive dedicated employees. Customers and channel partners typically suffer through all of these issues creating a poor customer experience and poor customer saticfaction ratings.

headline: Consulting Sales Executive
pros: Great company to work for. Well developed customer relationship and exciting products.
cons: Fickle in its approach to customers. Sales roles are challenging.

headline: Don't expect any job security
pros: Good people and good working conditions (except for a move to horrible open-plan offices - seriously, does anyone think that's a good idea?).
cons: I have worked there twice, and been laid off twice.  It doesn't matter how good you are or how hard you work, Autodesk periodically lays off whole departments.  So if you happen to work for the wrong manager, goodbye.  If you work there, just be aware that your job could suddenly end tomorrow.

headline: sr. software dev
pros: good working environment and nice colledges
cons: bad management and too many re-orgs

headline: Principal Engineer
pros:
1. Provides great benefits
2. Is an industry leader for almost all engineering fields that it addresses
3. Emphasis on innovation
4. Generous bonuses and stock option grants, frequently
5. Fantastic employee stock purchase plan
cons:
1. The company (or maybe the group I was working in) has pretty indiscriminate hiring policies
2.  Indiscriminate promotion policies -- quite a few incompetent managers
3. Very little interaction between industry groups, often leading to 'silo' products
4. Too many indiscriminate acquisitions

headline: Lots of layers
pros: I learned a lot at my short time at Autodesk. Some lessons were wonderful and I'll keep with me; other lessons are ones I hope I don't experience again.  Good news...the wonderful ones are more than the not-so-wonderful.   Overall, I'd give management a B. Some deserve an A and others deserve much worse but overall a pretty human organization with a strong base product. Try to get in with an A or a B.  Anything less and your life there will not be fun nor productive.
cons: For me, the organization and the structure did not fit my personality. There were too many layers of management.  During my time, the company was transitioning to a subscription based system and this seemed to make a lot of people nervous.  Budgets were cut several times and several lay-offs occurred during my short time there.  I put this under cons because management could have handled this differently and not have the stress that it put on many people restricting their creativity. Change is good and must be handled properly.

headline: Overall a great company to work for
pros:
Autodesk is a powerhouse and is doing a lot of pioneering work in the digital design space, not only in Architecture, Engineering, Construction (AEC) but in manufacturing, simulation, and even the media and entertainment space.  It's pretty cool to work for the original PC solution for CAD!
-Benefits are top-notch
-Very interesting problems to work on in the AEC/geometry/cloud/manufacturing/simulation space
-Strong marketing and sales organization leading the charge
-Great people tend to work here and you will be interacting with some top minds in the industry.
-Lots of mobility for motivated individuals
-Great office environments

Overall, If I had the chance to work here again, I would definitely take it.
cons:
This is a publicly traded company and brings along with it all the politics headaches and periodic "Reductions in Force" that accompany any big public company.  There's not much point in complaining about it.  It's all the same thing that brings all the great benefits and opportunities to work on cool problems.
-You will find that innovation, while valued, is painful and slow however, if you stick with it, there are definitely opportunities to innovate.
-You should be ok with not necessarily having your opinion valued on the larger picture items.  There is a corporate direction and that comes from the top, not the bottom in this company.  If you can be happy with that and are excited to tackle whatever challenge comes you will be very happy at this company, If you have vision and want to try and make change outside of your group, you will likely be disappointed.  
-I think you'll find Autodesk to be much like any large company.  If you really want to be able to influence change in an organization, look for a small startup.  I can't stress this enough: You will be successful here if you are happy doing your job as part of the big machine and not necessarily being able to see out to where you are going.  (regardless of what the "come work here" marketing hype suggests).  
-That said, note that there is a lot of internal opportunity for motivated individuals.  I've seen developers move to UI, QA people move to sales, developers move to product management, there is a LOT of opportunity here.

pros: It's a wonderful company to work for. Structured and well, how can you not like a company that involves itself in changing the world for the better? :D

headline: Suffocating politics
pros:
Great and bright coworkers
Great reputation
Lots of training options
Flexible work conditions
Lots of benefits
cons:
Even with all the pros, the cons are terrible.
The politics are suffocating. Having worked at even larger places than Autodesk, I'm surprised how bad the politics are.
Territorial, conflict averse, and often self-interest kills progress. 
Decisions take forever. 
Major layoffs are the norm now.
You could be a rockstar employee, but if you get caught in the politics, watch your back.
Every team is spread across the globe so expect late calls.
Way too many meetings too get simple things done.

headline: Ok, but micromanaged
pros: Great offices, the SF offices are amazing work spaces. Good benefits, the sabbatical is a unique benefit. Stable job, by the standards of the least stable industry in the world anyway. The senior level management seems to be genuinely intent on making the company a great place to work.  Interesting technologies and new concepts, fun to discuss the possibilities.
cons: In the sales org, you are held to weekly call metrics and activity reporting. If you come from a consultative environment and are used to managing your own schedule, it feels like a step back. There is more micromanagement than you would expect, primarily for the benefit of the bureaucracy. The sales management comes from a PC software sales environment instead of enterprise solutions environment, so the management model follows. Understand what you are signing up for as they make it sound like you are going to a solution sales company in the interview process.... There are a lot of cliques among the people who have been in place for years. Not that they will be outwardly hostile to new hires, but you kind of feel like you are not a full fledged member of the club.

headline: Autodesk review
pros: Benefits.  Excellent in-house training opportunities.  Superb facilities in Montreal especially if you are a cyclist (bike garage with tools, compressor, etc.).  Good life-balance if you land in the right team.  Open communication with senior management.
cons: Silos and politics are really painful.  Organisational overhead is particularly significant.  Significant layoffs almost every year.  Waterfall-ish despite claims to be Agile.  Entitlement and job preservation are often the main factor for decisions.

headline: Autodesk ranked 6 in best companies to work for 2015
pros:
I am very happy with the company. Recently, the company is ranked 6 in best companies to work for 2015. Here are some pros:
- International company with HQ in US and many other offices in India, China, etc. Practice Agile. 
- Good management. The manager's target is make Autodesk better place to work and employee happy.
- Good facility: You can made any request through an e-service system for facility. Every quarter, you boss will ask what peripheral you need for your working. The company provides accesses to many e-learning resources such as Linda, Safari. I love Safari where I can see many many books. 
- Many actives and benefits: Many awards every month, every quarter to recognize your effort. Birthday party every month. Sport club such as badminton. Provide dinner if you need to work OT on every Wednesday (actually, the company does not encourage you work OT. We are following Agile). Team outing activities every quarter. Too many for me to list.
- Friendly environment: Everyone is very friendly and approachable.
- Very good insurance and flex point program to claim. I must say this after comparing with my wife's insurance package.
cons: So far I don't see any cons

headline: Thnks for the Heads-up!

Toxic impression given by job advertisement:

1) "Ability to stand up to strong personalities" implies that HR condone behavior from management who lack Emotional Intelligence and do not know how to play well with others in the sandbox, manage by intimidation instead of getting the best out of their staff through positive interaction.

2)  "Listen, ask good questions, know when to speak up and when not to and understand the difference."

Again, this statement prompotes an atmosphere of fear and uncertainty, shuts down creative problem-solving and collaboration.

A very poor impression of management and HR department willing to condone and advertise for an opening in this manner.

They didn't care if customers complained because Autodesk's strategy is to buy up any potential product competitors so customers have no choice.  Horrible place to work if you care about producing quality products and giving customers what they need. Also, it suspiciously seemed that "older" folks were being "encouraged" to leave by offering the juicy projects to younger staff. Politics were toxic. headline: Fantastic Company
pros:
Autodesk is a company with strong ethics, and an inspiring vision and mission.  The company and most of the people who work for Autodesk seem to genuinely care about making the world a better place through intelligent design. 

Incredibly innovative and forward thinking in most business lines. CEO is responsive to staff, industry changes and market demands.  

Good benefits, but not the greatest & it will be increasingly difficult to retain talent as other tech companies double-down on benefits. Limited time off during the year is only (to some extent) supplemented by 6 week paid sabbatical every 4 years.  

Telecommuting / flexible work location for a lot of positions, which enables good work/life balance if you are diligent in playing your part to maintain balance (it is easy to work 24-7 & vacation days unless you go offline completely).
cons:
Many teams even within the same org operate in silos.  Very little sharing or communication between groups. Few feedback mechanisms between product and delivery teams, unless forged by individuals ad hoc (with such communication supported by their managers).  

Constant changes in management and yearly reorgs cause instability and loss of momentum.  Recovery periods from reorgs/management shifts are lengthy.  For a tech company, internal processes & communication channels are very outdated.  

Stock prices have decreased dramatically, and so has a substantial part of employee savings.  

Surprisingly political once you scratch the surface (which helps explain the frequent reorgs).

headline: Fortunate to work at Autodesk
pros: Very friendly and supportive environment; great SF location; CEO has a real vision for the company; sustainability and diversity actually matter and the company is making strides towards both; our customers make awesome things with our products (Bay Bridge, low-cost incubators for premature babies; sustainable buildings; Tesla).
cons: Communication between working teams is not part of the formal corporate culture; though high-level communications are shared, information needed to do daily jobs can be hard to discover.

headline: Position Review
pros: Friendly and vibrant atmosphere. There is always a wealth of knowledge and information to learn from creating a place to excel as much as one may wish to.
cons: A very large and complex company. It's a laborious task to have a procedure modified, or get a minor enhancement on a system tool set into place.

headline: Great product, company lacks strong direction
pros: The people at Autodesk are wonderful to work with, everyone is upbeat and positive.  Most positions offer a flexible working environment where you are able to work from home part or full-time.
cons:
In the marketing department it is incredibly bureaucratic in all of its processes.  The operations team controls all marketing platforms which makes it difficult to be nimble in making any changes or implementing new campaigns. 

Also, leadership team is inconsistent with their communications about the direction of the company.

headline: District Sales Manager
pros: Made good money but I think it was bought.
cons: It was bought by Autocad

headline: Great but fall short on Tech Support
pros:
Proud to work in Autodesk as the software it creates/acquire does help to create a better world. 
Learn a lot from smart people
cons:
Too many managers, little action, politics, silos
Employee's voice and feedback falls into blackhole
Little autonomy
Growth and development is pathetic

headline: Editor
pros: Fantastic and intelligent staff, excellent management, and a flexible schedule. People seemed very happy to be working there.
cons: I only wish i'd been hired on full-time! :>

headline: Salary is below par ...
pros: Great environment, innovative, importance to personal / family life, 6 weeks sabbatical
cons: Salary is dismal, bonus and options / rsus are practically non-existent, limited opportunity to grow...

headline: Solid Company
pros: Great place to work, strong leadership and values
cons: Going through a huge business model (and cultural) transformation

headline: Awesome place to work
pros: Great people, cool environment, cool products, and so much going on that it's great to be a part of. Lots of opportunity to contribute. The flexibility to work remotely is fantastic too.
cons: Too much work seems to be in silos. Duplicated efforts in various parts of the company leads to redundancy of effort and confusion sometimes.

headline: Software Engineer
pros:
work-life balance.
interesting projects in the pro design software field.
cons:
Less aggressive work environment, if you slack off, you will not be competitive gradually.
Some managers does not deserve their pay based on their ability.

headline: Cool office, average work
pros: Cool office, cool coworkers, minimal micromanagement
cons: Not very ambitious project design, poor communication between teams

headline: Flexible work, rigid structure
pros:
From a designer perspective, it's an environment where design has a strong voice, you don't have to fight for it as other tech companies. 
Flexible work hours, working from home, distance. 
Fancy and nicely located offices
cons:
No trajectory for career growth, especially if you are an individual contributor. 
Hard to output portfolio ready projects with too often changing directions.
Distributed teams, clashing agendas, black box decision making.

headline: Intern
pros: It was a very creative and collaborative culture. I felt I could go up to anyone and ask a question or for help. It was also nice being treated like a full-time employee instead of "just an intern"
cons: It seems like there's not a lot of collaboration between product teams. There's a lot of overlap between the products, since there are so many, and it seems pointless to continually reinvent the wheel.

headline: Weak Culture, Weak Leaders, Bad for Women
pros: Autodesk has a few great, market leading products. Some projects are interesting. Family friendly and good work-life balance even though some people abuse it.
cons:
Most senior leaders have been there forever. Many are weak. Failed to scale as company grew up but refuse to leave or step aside. Middle management is full of politicians who get ahead by kissing up.

It is a difficult culture for anyone to grow in, but especially for women leaders. HR is useless and only exists to protect the executives. That's what happened in IT, where the head of the division protected all his male buddies while seeing woman after woman punished, demoted or put on a plan out.

It's ok though, we all moved on and Autodesk has the IT group it deserves now.

headline: Excellent
pros: Dynamic forward looking company making  software tools for the future. Coworkers are the smartest people I've ever worked with and are passionate about our mission.
cons: Large corporation that grows primarily by acquisition. This and due to making a wide range of products tends to create cultural silos in the company.

headline: Good culture for a massive organization
pros: Autodesk was always looking for ways to expose their incredible technology to the interns, inside and outside of their respective departments.
cons: We still felt the obsolete pains of a traditional corporation, from lack of meaningful partnerships to the outdated timesheet services.

headline: A great learning experience
pros: Exciting and very creative environment. Freedom to experiment and come up with your own ideas which are appreciated. Excellent feedback and guidance provided from teammates who are a wealth of experience in their area.
cons: I just wish it was more than 10 weeks.

headline: Fantastic experience
pros: Very supportive and collaborative culture. Work style depends on team but good people in general. My team gave me good visibility into the overall business they were looking into and let me drive my project independently, though they were always there to help out. They also genuinely cared for me and were invested in the internship. Brownie points - SF one market and pier 9 offices are out of the world. What a thrill to get the bay bridge and ferry building view from the window of one market :) intern events and tech talks were fun too!
cons: Need to be self driven and take complete ownership, ask for help when needed and network within the organisation to get required info.

headline: Software Engineering - Intern
pros:
Best Manager - Very Motivational and Helpful
World Class Salary - I was paid the highest salary autodesk can offer
Immense Learning Curve - If you have the crave to learn new stuffs and work in an environment or product containing millions of LOC then autodesk is the place to work
cons:
Very Competitive - Most of the colleagues are very experienced and smart people so we have to work hard to compete with others
Sometimes need to work long hours to get things completed, because all the products are very complex architectural design

headline: Autodesk Internship
pros: community, health benefits, intern programming, location, intern olympics
cons: communication across departments, interns spread across different locations

headline: Good Big Company
pros: Organized Big Company, No need work overtime in most of time. Benefits and salary are good too.
cons:
Your ideas may not be converted into reality due to company strategy, focus, etc.
And you may work on one area for long time.

headline: Nice place to work
pros: Good work environment. It's a great company to work for the products and technology are incredible, people are nice.
cons: Nothing to say. None that I can think of!

headline: Needs a management purge
pros: Great benefits, some smart people and some great teams to work with if you're lucky.  Is an understanding company for a working parent.   Cool legacy products and devoted customers!
cons: Management has become horrific in some teams. There is no "holocracy" here!  Since managers can't lead and inspire by their vision and personality,  in some teams managers are encouraged to tell their people in every 1-1 if they would hire them again.  This is from some "management guru" being brought in (at significant expense i'm sure)  to advise the Autodesk corporation on how to make a turn around and become a more innovative company.  Regular intimidations of the programmers in an attempt to appear modern and innovative shows lack of integrity that seems to pervade the middle management at this company.

headline: Information doesn't travel north.
pros: Great people, Great products, in my estimation the best development company on the planet.,
cons: If you have put in over 20 years of service don't expect to be around much longer. Autodesk disdains experience in their own organization, but jumps at any hire from a competitor thinking they hold the key to success. Long term planning means >12 mos. The company easily tires of new initiatives, fast! Reality is not recognized at Autodesk. Perception guides everything at the company. Autodesk will tell you they are a leader in the manufacturing space. Nothing could be further from the truth. Autodesk is an also-ran, and barely a thought at the biggest and best manufacturers. Yet, they spent years telling employees and customers they were leading. Self delusion is not a corporate virtue!

headline: Love my team, hate my salary
pros: I absolutely love my team, the office's location, and my manager. Autodesk is pretty relax with my hours (ill come in between 9 and 10:30), and usually allow me to work from home if I want to travel.
cons: I believe I am being under paid. I understand that I have less than one year of experience but as an average salary for a developer in San Francisco, I believe I am on the extreme low end.

headline: Not impressed with leadership
pros: I was employed for many years.  It's a great company to work for...smart, dedicated people and fantastic products.
cons: I find the executive leadership team weak and question how they reward employees.  Not impressed with the level of thought leadership.

headline: Business System Analyst - EIS
pros:
Autodesk is doing really awesome things and they make sure that the mission and values of the company are front an center regardless of which organization you are a part of. 

Development of professional skills is incredibly important, especially for those working in EIS. Courses in communication, management, productivity software, and role-specific technologies are available to all employees and managers are given a generous budget for educational expenses.
cons: For a tech company with offices in SF, there is definitely an air of old-school corporate culture. Very few fringe benefits compared to most modern Silicon Valley tech companies. Lots of bureaucracy and top-down reorganizations occurred on a quarterly basis, most on the whim of a single manager higher up. Issues with competency with many of my peers in EIS.

headline: Interesting work and friendly work environment
pros: Work is interesting and challenging with always lots to do.  Colleagues are friendly and helpful with everyone always pulling together to get things done.
cons: Small Heath isn't the nicest area of Birmingham but has good public transport and road links plus there's ample onsite parking.  Birmingham itself has vastly improved for night life over the last 10 years.

headline: Great products, horrible management
pros: There's a lot of energy in the C-level around our products and direction.  Really exciting long term strategy and growth potential.
cons: I don't think they'll ever reach the long term potential because middle management seems to be really incompetent.  Most of the managers and individual contributors seem most skilled at keeping their job rather than moving the needle and making significant change to drive those long term strategies set by executives.

headline: Great products, horrible management
pros: There's a lot of energy in the C-level around our products and direction.  Really exciting long term strategy and growth potential.
cons: I don't think they'll ever reach the long term potential because middle management seems to be really incompetent.  Most of the managers and individual contributors seem most skilled at keeping their job rather than moving the needle and making significant change to drive those long term strategies set by executives.

headline: So far, so good
pros: I am a fairly new employee but so far it has been a great experience.  The benefits are very good, the people are really nice, I have a great manager, and interesting work projects.
cons: Honestly, none so far.  I have worked at a couple companies before with some significant cons, so I can tell the difference!  This company has many of the same challenges as everywhere else, but it seems to be handling it much better than every other place I have worked before.

headline: A lifetime of learning at Autodesk
pros:
The larger corporate structure at Autodesk is pursuing high-value long term goals and working to open up silos and equip employees for years of future success.

The work we are doing is cutting edge and highly experimental and challenging.  We work with an amazing team of really smart people doing work we love.
cons: The larger corporate structure can sometimes feel unwieldy and difficult to navigate.  Sometimes decisions seem arbitrary and understanding what is going on can come at a premium.

headline: Great place to work!
pros: Opportunities for employee development.  Management truly values its employees feedback  and takes actions annually.  Very flexible work environments!
cons: None that I can think of!

headline: Program Manager
pros:
1. Innovative, inspiring company
2. the company treats employees well. good benefits
3. great learning and growth opportunity. There are lots of interesting training and speeches.
4. friendly and professional coworkers
cons: haven't noticed any yet. happy employee

headline: Mediocre leadership, no vision, negative work culture in India
pros: Company's reputation and good products. Good if you are in the development team.
cons:
Leadership is focused on their own commissions at the cost of employee's well being
Mediocre management in India t lack vision
High attrition in India as manipulative management focus on divide and rule
No freedom to work independently
No career growth
Autodesk US is completely different from Autodesk India. Don't get fooled!

headline: Great culture and interesting work.
pros: Tons of interesting work. Very busy dependent on the group you work in. There is a lot of room to bring forth and execute on ideas. Managers are nice and care about employees.
cons: Sometimes you find yourself taking work home. Not sure if this is a con, or more of a result of being so interested in the work.

headline: Adminstrative Assistant
pros: Autodesk has amazing products!  Software that let's designers, architects, engineers, etc. do awesome things.  Many people have never heard of the company but know their products like AutoCAD.  The culture of the company is one that values their employees.  They do barbecues at some of their offices.  People can take their dogs to work.  They are big on employee development and give lots of opportunity for personal and professional growth.  They encourage community involvement!  The pay and benefits were great!
cons: They grew very quickly while I was there and hired lots of people in my division.  When the recession hit, they needed to quickly cut back on employees and laid off 750 in the first round of layoffs and about 400 more a few months later.

headline: Intern
pros: It was great working here as an intern. The management values your opinion and gives you the flexibility and opportunity to pursue your interests.
cons: I have nothing negative about this company.

headline: Autodesk Singapore isn't a good place you want to be
pros: Salary is on time, always.
cons: Some coworkers are smart but most have lost a passion for the doing the right thing. Office politics is all over the Singapore office.

headline: Sourcing Manager
pros: Good people and great offices.  Systems in place to support functions.  There is a pretty good stock purchase plan for employees.  Also, they have a pretty competitive benefits package.  Also, espresso machine on every floor.
cons: Long hours, global schedule, so you may have to join done really early our really late calls.  If you have to commute to the HQ, it can be a challenge.

headline: Almost great
pros: Compelling technology and interesting customers solving real world problems that are truly motivational; plus the current transition to cloud-based solutions and subscription licensing is an interesting business challenge
cons: Hard to connect the dots in such a "matrixed" organization for a great customer experience; organizing by industry perspective can make it seem like at least 3 or 4 different companies instead of 1

headline: A well run company
pros: Autodesk is a well run company with competitive compensation and benefits. They are cognizant of work life balance and try to treat people well. I have been lucky enough to have managers that encourage my professional development.
cons: Autodesk is big enough that bureaucracy can get in the way of progress. It can be frustrating to prioritize tasks and otherwise get things done.

headline: Good company - I miss it
pros:
Excellent people
Great technology
Cool headquarters
Cool gallery on Market street in downtown SF
Solid benefits
Infrequent travel
cons:
Hard to move up
People don't leave the company
Low-ish pay compared to other Bay Area companies
HQ isn't near SV
Seniority and tenure rewarded

headline: Excellent
pros: Excellent company, Great Products, Great People. Excellent benefits. The company places a great amount of emphasis on how people are treated , developing them etc. So an employee these things are generally highly valued. Great work-life flexibility too.
cons: very old company, so you need to know how to get the machinery moving to get things done. Sometimes the top management needs to dictate mandates to drive alignment. Doing it bottoms up seems very difficult.

headline: Interesting if you like making
pros: Great people, opportunity to use a great workshop
cons: It's operated completely in a different way in some group. In the group I was in, middle management decided that we have to be on-site Monday through Friday.

headline: Business Manager in Chile
pros: Manage Autodesk Business in Chile through Channel partners in order tu achieve sales and profit plans.
cons: Little chance of career development

headline: Great autonomy and flexibility in work
pros:
You get to plan and work at your desired pace, so long as you complete all the tasks required of you properly by the end of every week
You are expected to be independent and resourceful but superiors are friendly and will always be there to guide you if you need it
Business casual attire
cons: Repetitive work which may get boring after some time

headline: Good and bad, just like any other company
pros:
The public perception is great because of the innovative things being done in places like Pier 9. It's cool seeing the Autodesk logo on video game splash screens. I am proud to tell people that I work for Autodesk.

The benefits are incredible. Health, vision, dental, 401k, ESPP, stock gifting based on performance. Healthcare providers frequently tell me that they've never seen health insurance as good as ours. Vision insurance pays for an eye exam each year plus glasses or contacts for every member of my family. The PTO is generous and there is no limit on sick time. Every 4 years employees are provided with a 6 week paid sabbatical to be used at any time within the next 4 years.

Employees are given the proper tools to do their jobs.
cons:
While telecommuting is available in certain situations, it is becoming more and more rare to hire someone not located near an office. It often seems as if good talent is being passed over in favor of having chairs being filled in offices.

Opportunities for career growth are based on politics rather than performance. If you ask why then you aren't dedicated to your job.  Some employees are able to jump from job to job and stay fresh, while others are overlooked and become stagnant.

Middle management - my biggest gripe. Employee disbursements look like a bell curve. C Level is pretty standard for any corporation, Once you start going down the ladder into middle management it swells like a balloon. Leave middle management and go on down the chain and it tapers back off. Any given person may have to answer to a number of people, and most of them contradict each other. All hands meetings are mostly spent focusing on one subject that only appeals to a small segment of the audience. Any news delivered can't be 100% trusted because by the time the next one comes around the process will have changed 10 times. Middle management "interprets" what they take out of those meetings and regurgitates it in a completely unrecognizable form.
