cons: Autodesk is becoming a Software holding company, buying up competition and relegating their older portfolio to maintenance mode. The management tends to blame the worker and not other managers for missing margins and lays off workers without thinning the ranks of management. The result is a top heavy company with alot of management and noone to actually execute the plan.

headline: Decent place to work but upset that the headquarters are now in San Francisco
pros: Dogs are allowed to be here
cons: Overseas outsourcing has lowered the quality of our producs

headline: Excellent company creating amazing software used by many creative individuals and industries
pros: My colleagues are brilliant and hardworking individuals. There are many different types of projects to work on. Six-week sabbaticals every four years are nice. Autodesk has a bright future for delivering great products to creative individuals around the world.
cons: No additional vacation days for longer employment. Teams working on specific initiatives, features, or products are largely local so advancement outside a particular group, generally means relocation.

headline: Good, bad & ugly
pros:
Amazing, dedicated customer and channel base
Phenominal technology/products
Great flexibility in terms of work-at-home options
Sabbatical program that makes all the BS almost worth it
cons:
Lack of sophistication & commitment at senior levels in terms of brand building and marketing
"Management by consensus" at the C-staff level makes it difficult to move things forward
Lots of reorgs and restacks that don't seem to make things better, only more confusing

headline: Good company to work for.
pros: Stable company. Respects employees. Okay compensation.
cons: Always late in the game as per as adopting new technologies and integrating that to the products.

headline: Great products but unstable management and strategies
pros:
- Great software product lines including 2D/3D CAD, simulation, media, architecture etc
- Nice co-workers and inter-communication/corporation style
- Above average office
- Okay Pay and benefit
cons:
- Very unstable management strategies in simulation product
- Does not focus on core simulation technologies

headline: Great Place to Work
pros: Great Salary, Great Peers,  Office setting, and Bonuses
cons: Stressful and Demanding.  You can work hard all day and still be behind.

headline: I have a very high opinion of Autodesk
pros:
Culture, Diversity, Flexibility, Products, Philosophy.

Autodesk has been and continue to be a great place to work. There is a lot of energy in the company and people are highly motivated and driven
cons: I have nothing negative to report about Autodesk

headline: Great place to work
pros:
Good compensation
Very high quality products and reputation
Dedicated, very intelligent employees
Executives all approachable, most are straight-shooters
Always listed on 'top places to work" surveys
cons:
Large bureaucracy with lots of divisions, departments, teams, and criss-crossing responsibilities
Company does medium to large re-orgs every couple of years
Lots of mid-level manager with not a lot of growth opportunities
Poor to non-existent HR function in terms of professional growth

headline: Great place for a career!
pros:
Promotes work/life balance and a very caring culture.
Significant growth of the Company has provided development opportunities (at least laterally) for staff.
Competitive compensation plans.
cons:
Lots of people stay a long time which means getting vertical climb is difficult.
Lack of real focus to drive change - transformational change is not always successful.
Overly-collaborative culture makes it hard to make decisions and move forward.

headline: I worked with a great group of people on an exciting product.
pros: Great people to work with.
cons: Very little cross project collaboration

headline: Autodesk is a great place to work
pros: Autodesk is a leader in CAD, BIM, VFX, and 3D animation technologies, and is one of the most important technology vendors in all of its markets. Working at Autodesk is a privilege; you get to work with some of the brightest and most talented people on the planet, who love what they do.
cons: Autodesk is a bit decentralized, making it a bit chaotic if you need to bridge multiple industry groups as part of your job. Autodesk lacks a culture of grooming great managers. It hires very talented people, and it does invest in them, but there is no general ethos of building people up to make them great leaders; you need to figure out how to do this on your own, and find your own path. Also, Autodesk acquires many companies, and typically the leaders of acquired companies get moved to key management roles, leaving the folks who have been in trenches still in the trenches. It can be disheartening.

headline: very good place to work
pros: very good place to work
cons: very frequent changes create questions in people's mind

headline: Good company, but weak operational management and execution.
pros: Good company benefits and treatment of employees.  Generally, nice people to work with and collaborate.  Some very scary smart people at Autodesk.
cons: The scary smart people should not necessarily be in leadership positions.  Carl Bass as CEO is very weak CEO.  He is practical, smart, and somewhat visionary.  He does not provide clear direction and is generally looks at the negative at most things.  The company has an eclectic culture due to so many acquisitions so the leadership should really work to integrate teams and work on this more diligently.

headline: Great company
pros: Hardworkers are rewarded well for their efforts.
cons: Work life balance can be difficult.

headline: Autodesk is full of smart people working on a great strategy
pros: Organization is full of smart people.  Overall the company provides good compensation and benefits and flexibility to work from home.   If you love dogs, this is the place to be because you can bring your dog to work.
cons: Organization going through change management effort as they have changed their go to market strategy to move from product focus to consumer focus.

headline: Still a great place to work, with a word of caution.
pros: Co-workers are passionate and civilized , good company benefits, working atmosphere is stimulating.  Company has an excellent environmental policy, great and beautiful locations.
cons: When employees are already putting a lot of hours, If the middle manager wants to look good, you might be under a lot of unnecessary stress. Difficult to control and talk about career path. Also, In recent years, work efficiency has improved but the technical services to employees did not scale, waiting too long and too much red tape for things to be setup correctly.

headline: Impressive products, hopeful business roadmap - but not necessarily a top place to work.
pros: Salaries seem to be pretty generous.  Product suite is innovative and exciting, which made me proud to be a part of that growth.  Surrounded by very smart and articulate people.
cons: Job description was misleading.  I felt pigeon holed when I got there, due to the extremely siloed and bureaucratic org.  Lots of aggressive career climbers.  Very colorful and creative office environment, but a very corporate culture in the end.  No sense of sharing and community.  And WAY too many meetings - most of the time with very little result.

headline: Great work life balance but does not know what it is doing in simulation
pros: Autodesk has some of the best softwares in digital design. It is a laid back company and offers employees a lot of flexibility in terms of work hours. Working from home is widely accepted. The benefits offered are extremely generous, even to the laid off employees. They are investing a lot of money on what they think is the wave of the future, which for them is cloud based solution capabilities and PLM in engineering softwares.
cons:
1. The company gives only one earned day leave per month which can not be used ahead of time.
2. The company is bottom heavy and there are very few opportunities for advancement of career. 
3. The people in the upper echelon gets promoted by being good at internal politics. 
4. Some of the managers may not have a good understanding of the area they are trying to manage.
5. The company does not have a good understanding of simulation business but wants to be a simulation leader. Upper management does not even understand the difference between a convergent valid solution and a convergent garbage result when it comes to simulation and as a result they are pushing for low cost, snazzy looking simulation products for the future which would end up giving garbage results for any complicated simulation especially in FEA / multi-physics domain. 
6. They want to be a leader in simulation product business and yet are aiming for those customers who may not quite understand the physics of simulation and could be made happy with any results regardless of the accuracy of it as long as their software produces a result.

headline: Great products, nice people, only OK senior management but great CEO
pros: Fantastic products that are changing the world.  But innovation comes via purchasing external companies/products and there are few new internal products created that have a significant revenue impact.
cons: VP and SVP level frequently throw in feature requests and product scope changes that are not grounded on data and result in a worse product.  Lots of scope change, slow product development, and low product quality as a result.

headline: Amazing and thoughtful, creative and collaborative
pros: Creativity and edgy. Autodesk is open minded and the products are amazing.
cons: Salary and some cultural limitations. Managment is poor and needs to be hired.

headline: Good company to work to start your career
pros: Product company, leaders in CAD, CAM domain also leaders in Media , having good softwares like AutoCAD, Maya and 3D studioMax
cons:
processes are worst
no opportunity for growth
driven by people who really want work in groups, third person hardly gets adjusted

headline: Great lifestyle company
pros: Great lifestyle company; ability to work from home is widely accepted and there is no facetime. Sabbatical program is highly touted and encourages employees to stay for long periods of time -- 6 wks off every 4 years.
cons: PTO policy is stingy. When I was there you got 10 days PTO per year. There are forced shutdown weeks to save costs, and you must use your PTO balance for those forced shutdown days/weeks and/or go without pay.

headline: Great place to work, learn and grow your career
pros: Leading technology company enabling amazing creations from our users.  Lot's of opportunities for upward growth and promotion. Fairly flat organizational structure.  Open communication from leadership down to the individual contributor. World class engineers and designers solving tough problems.
cons: Sometimes a bit too political...huge organization with shifting strategies ... Work life balance is okay but could be better.

headline: Big ship changing course
pros: Smart people, good benefits.  Solid innovation culture.
cons: Low salaries.  Ancient system of advancement (be here long enough),  pockets of massive waste (e.g.ineffective and bloated marketing team, redundant development projects). No apparent M&A strategy.

headline: Senior research engineer
pros: A great company to work for. It has very good benefits and work-life balance. The main business, CAD, is very dominating and essentially a cash cow. It has bought and continues to buy into many different industries.
cons: It does not understand, nor does it care much, about what it bought. For example, We were in a simulation company bought by Autodesk a few years back. It not only successfully destroyed the business, but also laid off most of talented tech guys.

headline: VP's focused on protecting their own Asses first - Delivering great services second
pros: Product groups are working on incredible products and services.  If you consider a job at Autodesk, make sure it is within one of the product divisions.  Outside of those organizations, you are taking a big risk.
cons:
Corporate staff engrained with "old timers" who have significant power and make sure they use that power to drive their own agendas.  I have never been more excited to work somewhere and have never been more disappointed.

In some areas there is work life balance, but it all depends on who you work for.

headline: Great company with strong desire to grow and evolve to meet the customer's needs and drive innovation.
pros: Good benefits, flexible hours, encouragement to grow and develop skill set.
cons: Internal communication are sometimes fuzzy.

headline: Great company to work for
pros:
Working for a leader in the industry
very diverse range of jobs
focus on career development
ability to work almost anywhere
cons:
Big corporate machine
Can sometimes feel a disconnect with executive staff
hard to change the way things work
Change happens slowly

headline: Great place to work, but C-Staff lacks focus and discipline
pros: Great people, great products, nice working environment, opportunities for career moves within company. Excellent benefits.
cons: Half-baked reorganizations that don't make business sense are a regular event. It feels as if C-staff isn't able to make hard decisions. There is a still an old-boys/friends of Carl club. Not many women at the highest levels.

headline: Innovative Company
pros: Big company with Start up DNA.
cons: Volume dstrubution company moving to global enterprise model.

headline: Autodesk seems to have forgotten that  satisfied employees make the company successful
pros:
Benefits
Flexible work hours
interesting people
cons:
Culture shift from respecting employees, which in turn made them work harder, to ignoring employees input.
Long time employees often manged out
Employee Engagement no longer a priority (even though they say it is)

headline: Great company with great benefits and upward mobility
pros: Salary, benefits, company vision, and opportunity for growth
cons: Some management has gotten a reputation for micromanaging employees.

headline: Program Manager - Strategy & Transformation
pros:
Data driven decision making
Hungry for success
cons:
Excessive expenditure on account managers, who are paid for driving partner sales into large accounts.
Marketing heavy company with little knowledge of credible customer success stories in their region

headline: An illustration in how a few individuals can create so many issues
pros:
Work life balance.
Smart and talented employees who are passionate
Decent benefits
Modern Office Space
cons:
Leadership
Years after the Revit acquisition the direction is largely set by a team that came from a long discontinued and dead end product line. They promote and defend each other to the exclusion of all others.  Decision making takes forever - everything has to be run up and down the line by sycophantic middle managers who just rubber stamp trying to please their boss.  Productivity and moral suffer despite multiple visits from consultants, internal surveys, and huge delivery failures.  More than half the time in a  week is devoted to bureaucratic overhead and micromanagement.  Expect little in the way of tuition re-imbursement, travel,  conferences, software while the favored clic blow millions on failed projects outside the companies core competency. The main issues and individuals are never dealt with - more like a government agency than a private company.  Talented people have been leaving at a high rate and new hires quickly realize the mistake they made.  Still no changes.

headline: Abuse is allowed for some sad reason
pros:
Good benefits
Nice people...for the most part
cons: Management is allowed to verbally abuse people; no one cares...not the higher ups and not HR.  It's simply allowed.

headline: Lots of support for new hires
pros: New hires receive a good relocation package. Fellow employees and managers are very welcoming.
cons: The commute to the Waltham office is tough -- it's a bit far from public transit...and anything else!

headline: Good place to work
pros: Chance to work on product development from scratch
cons: Project planning fluctuates a lot

headline: Great experience, great people, great office..!!
pros: Autodesk is the best place to start your career as an intern. It s a very good learning experience. All the people in the office are very modest and encouraging. They provide every intern with great support, guidance and motivation. The most important objective in this company is learning. And then applying the knowledge. Its the perfect way to start a new career into the IT industry.  I don’t think it could get any better than this..!
cons: None. I dont think there can be any cons of working at Autodesk. The only thing that made me unhappy was the end of my internship term. :(

headline: Great flexibility!
pros: Work life balance second to none. Great flexibility (telecommuting, flex hours, hotelling). Mid and top-level management in most business divisions is dated (but open to ideas) )which means if you have fresh ideas and newer skills, there are ample opportunities to prove yourself and move up.
cons: Not enough young blood and fresh ideas. Need to find the right teams else work will go unnoticed.

headline: Great people, great benefits, great experience
pros:
- Great trust with employees (I worked remotely)
- unlimited sick days
- telecommuting benefits (could work from home 2 days a week)
- Great managers
- Talented employees
cons:
- A layoff a year it seems
- Many managers as a result

headline: Software Engineer
pros: It is quite good if you are interested in CAD industry since it dominates the whole industry.  Also internally you will learn different technics as the project varies soon (half year or one year).
cons: It is just so so to me, not so attractive any more. The office in Singapore does not grows well as the project is not quite interesting and also it is not easy to get promoted. Usually it takes 5~6 year to get to next level which does not motivates the employee much.

headline: People oriented
pros: Accommodates individual lifestyles Never fires top level staff - lateral transfers instead. Can bring dogs to work. Gym on premises at headquarters. Flexible work hours including working at home.
cons: Top heavy. Never fires top level staff - lateral transfers instead. Can bring dogs to work. Innovation rare, mostly advances by acquisition. Information not shared down the ranks. Layoffs timed to quarterly earnings and share prices

headline: Open your Eyes
pros:
The benefits are good
You interact with many different cultures arouns he world.
cons:
Management and them being blind to the truth.
Managements lack of respect with regards to employees 
Confidential information.
Managmenet threatening their employees, with statements
Such as "I will pull the trigger like I did to so n so".
Management micro management of employees.
Management's lack of knowledge of what everyone in
The departments job functions are.
Telling management the truth about whats happening.
Human resources as they make you believe they are on 
Side, when they always back the company or manager.

headline: Autodesk: Exciting Place to work
pros:
- Great Culture
- Dynamic
- Winners
- Creative
- Mega talented staff
- Great offices
- Great compensation package (Many companies in the recession are cutting benefits, Autodesk have paid annual bonus and maintained full benefits package.  Much credibility to them).
- Going into new markets eg Consumer is exciting
cons:
- Few outside of the industry have heard of the Autodesk brand or name.

This is very frustrating as its a hidden gem of a company.  Great to work for and its products help design most of the world around us, be it cars, planes, building, bridges, visual effects in films (eg Avatar, Inception, Lord of the Rings), and most of the videogames today.  Very cool but very unknown.

headline: Good Company, great products!! ...But they have a Passive/Agressive Culture.
pros: Great perks!  Great benefits, bring your dog to work in some locations, flex time, etc. Good training and development programs, possible career growth, but very polictical. Nice people...everyone is friendly.Great products.
cons: Their motto is work hard, play hard...and it is very demanding company. They don't do conflict well.  If you disagree with the status quo, you are looked at as a trouble maker.  So, everyone agrees with the status quo, but trashes this issues or problems behind managements back.  They don't talk about the 'white elephant' in the room or are direct about anything.  Very polictical.

headline: Hardworking yet fun company that values user experience; you get to work on invaluable industry-leading software.
pros: Great culture in San Francisco office. Talented and hardworking team members. Great benefits and supportive managers. Product team really values users in the design and development process. Constantly doing user research and usability.
cons: A lot of politics, re-orgs, company sometimes feels like teams working in siloes. Challenging at times to work with teams dispersed across locations/timezones.

headline: Good place to start and retire
pros: Nice culture, good work/life balance
cons: Not much opportunities for career development

headline: Good place to start and retire
pros: Nice culture, good work/life balance
cons: Not much opportunities for career development

headline: Right change in strategy - poor execution as usual.
pros:
- Major change in strategy laid out clearly.
- Great pay and stock plan.
- Vacation and other benefits are so-so but ok.
- Global reach and usually get to work with very smart people.
cons:
- Disastrous execution of reorg.  
- Good growth (>50%) products getting sidelined due to VP's pet project.
- Weak middle management that does not question upper management decisions or edicts.
- Very very political.  Cannot be honest.
- Fringe benefits are gone.  No more dogs in most offices.  No drinks or snacks.
- Travel is a pain.

headline: hey, it is a job
pros: there is a lot of CAD
cons: managing up is what it's all about

headline: Good place to work
pros: Good work culture and work environment
cons: Salaries and Benefits given the cost of living in singapore

headline: Top Down Mercenary Management in some Divisions
pros: There are a lot of  great people to work with. Decisions can be made quickly and they have the money to make things happen. Great office in SFO.
cons: Management of the Manufacturing division only look up for input and then command those under them to do it. They give you all the leeway you need - to do things their way.

headline: The company tries to do the right thing but is rather dysfunctional.
pros: Nice headquarters.  Largely cool people but you run across quite a few "it's not my job" type of people even though it is their job for some basic things I needed from them.
cons: There is a severe lack of process there.  For every little thing you do, you have to reinvent the wheel every single time.  Meetings, meetings and more meetings.  This can't totally be avoided because of the geographically dispersed offices, but half the meetings can easily be cut out.

headline: A great place to work
pros: Great Benefits and great products.
cons: Some bureaucracy....way too many meetings sometimes.

headline: Friendly place to work, opportunities to advance
pros:
advancement opportunities - with great work and the right manager
friendly atmosphere
global company, with focus on different industries
leadership training offered
innovative culture
creative
cons:
too frequent reorgs
dysfunctional teams
too many internal meetings
execution varies
promotions are not all merit based
should invest more in manager training

headline: so so
pros:
feels like a small company
changes made fast
cons:
very political
incompetent managers
teams work in isolation

headline: Great place to work
pros: flexible, great benefits, decent pay, lots of opportunities to learn
cons: hard to move up the ladder or get pay increases once you are in.

headline: Penance
pros: Benefits are above average for industry
cons: Weak middle management, little accountability

headline: One big oportunity
pros: Extending skills in wide range of IT area. Meet a lot of people from different countries across the world. Learn how to work in big teams.  See new and inovative technologies.
cons: Sometimes  worse communication with managers they are far away from our office and communicate in different languages. Hard to watch what is Autodesk going to be, what are the plans. Sometimes hard to enforce ideas.

headline: Cannot improve my tenichnical skill too much
pros: You do not have to overtime work
cons: Too relax cannot improve too much

headline: opportunities are based on politics and self serving management
pros: very good benefits, very good professional training, good industry penetration. great customers. Autodesk is a good short term stepping stone opportunity.
cons: poor compensation opportunities. no focus on what is right for the customer, only focus is right for quarterly revenue. targets are profit based, not customer opportunity based. promotes. advancement at the expense of what is right or on damage to others.

headline: Overall, great place to learn and grow.
pros: Fast paced, creative, challenging environment.
cons: Work is often done in siloes.

headline: Positive work environment, smart colleagues
pros: collaborative, very smart peers, and great work life balance.
cons: Below par compensation leading to dissatisfaction

headline: Great place to work!
pros: Great benefits, emphasis on work/life balance, smart people
cons: Normal pitfalls of a larger company, it can be easy to fall through the cracks or not get training opportunities if you aren't proactive

headline: Good place to work
pros:
Good benefits including paid six week sabbatical every 4 years.
Smart people building good and important products.
Strong focus on sustainability.
CEO is a visionary and real (unlike some tech CEOs).
cons:
Frequent / annual org changes impact productivity.
Organizational ADD.
Indifferent marketing and branding - nobody knows who we are and what we do.

headline: Autodesk is a Great Place if you play the potical game with Managment
pros: Great Benefits n good people in various areas of the company, just not managment.
cons: Managment's lack of knowledge of their employee job duties. Doesnt handle conflict directly and shoves it under the carpet.

headline: great work life balance but you need to find the right group
pros: family oriented and supports work life balance
cons: career development opportunities can be poor and far between

headline: great work life balance but you need to find the right group
pros: family oriented and supports work life balance
cons: career development opportunities can be poor and far between

headline: A great place to grow, innovate, and work with driven team members.
pros: Autodesk has a competitive spirit and a culture of highly motivated team membres that are driven to acheive leadership's vision.
cons: If you aren't driven to work hard, innovate often, and adapt to change, the fast-pace world of technology won't be a good fit.

headline: internally focused, channel gets the business, no customer centric DNA
pros:
stable & steady due to commanding market position in engineering design software industry
channel gets most of the business
relative to other companies in similar space, OK HR practices
cons:
Totally internalized perspective due to market share; very little customer focus or centricity 

Not exciting from a sales & marketing stand-point; management prefers slow & steady versus any disruptive opportunities 

Behaves like a giant ship, not agile

Constant re-structuring; confused senior management with no idea of customer & employee issues ; happy in their silos drawing in the big bucks

headline: I'm surrounded by geniuses
pros: A great place to work, i'm constantly impressed with the level of talent of the people I work with, smart, clever, easy to get along with and always at the top of their game.
cons: Sometimes it feels like you can't change things from the bottom up, however it is very easy to go talk directly to senior management, to get your voice heard, so its rarely a problem.

headline: Excellent and interesting experience.
pros:
good chance.
new technology.
good salary.
chance to travel.
stable.
cons:
not comparable salary.
treat people from different country different salary.

headline: Amazing company, products and people!
pros:
Fantastic products and company strategy and direction are inspiring!  
Excellent work/life balance and people are smart, talented and respectful.    It's a dynamic, global company with tremendous opportunities to challenge yourself and grow.   Great office environments and benefits are outstanding!   The executive team is intelligent and down to earth.
cons:
Performance needs to be dealt with more aggressively as there are some people who are not meeting the current bar of performance.    
Global company means meetings at odd times but the flexible work environment enables you to work around this so you're not working 24 hours a day!

headline: Incredibly smart and driven team that strives for quality
pros: Very smart engineering team that strives for high quality code and product dev, including attention to detail, clean well-architected code, and taking the time to do it right, instead of rushing something out the door.  Both the head of engineering and lead architect are always willing to listen to feedback and take other peoples ideas into consideration.  Free drinks and snacks.
cons: Demanding work environment that may not fit the typical 9-5 lifestyle.  Low tolerance for imperfection or sloppy coding.  Very little in the way of fun company activities.

headline: Great time to work for Autodesk
pros: I've worked for Autodesk for almost seven years.  I worked for four other employers previously; non-profit, for-profit, Fortune 50, high-tech, no-tech, ect.  This is the best of them all and I'm not thinking about leaving.  Autodesk has the benefits of an established company in a fast-paced and innovative industry.  It is truly a global company with equal amounts of revenue coming from AMER, EMEA and APAC.  It is a good company; kind to the environment, fair to employees and contributes positively to the communities where it is located.  Carl Bass, the CEO, socializes with employees, especially on a field, track or court.
cons: Often long and odd hours; calls at 10:00 pm and 6:00 am.  People get in here and stay, so you really have to impress to get ahead.  Poor performers are not always dealt with so you have to work around them.

headline: basically it is a good place...
pros:
Work life balance. Not sure about guys work in other project, but working time is quite flexible. 
Nice building and working condition. 
Medical insurance covers the whole family.
cons:
Promotion opportunity is limited.
Desktop app is not hot in the market now.
Some unqualified colleagues. It would be a disaster if happen to work with them.
Not a good place for growth.

headline: Good employees, cool products but management could use improvement.
pros:
Decent work life balance most of the time
Good benefits plus 6 week sabbatical for U.S. employees every 4 years
Really like the new consumer products area Autodesk is getting into
Casual work environment
cons:
Too many meetings about nothing
Pay is mainly in the mid-range, although senior management is paid very well
Individual contributors are not well compensated - you need to be a manager to have a decent salary
Most mid-level managers manage their teams poorly - they need more training
Non-revenue generating departments are extremely tight with their budgets and stretch their employees
Annual employee survey doesn't show much results
Carl Bass doesn't have company wide meetings
